At that time, the TathÄgata remained silent and did not reply.

At that time, Ä€nanda was holding a fan and attending to the Buddha, fanning him. Having heard what Udraka had asked, he said to him:

It is like a border city with strong walls and sturdy ramparts, with railings and windows all firmly constructed.
The streets, alleys, government offices, and markets are arranged in an orderly manner, without confusion.
But this city has only one gate.
The gatekeeper is wise and intelligent, has a great power of memory, and is well able to distinguish guests and old acquaintances. He lets in those he knows and blocks those he does not.

At that time, the people in the city who wanted to leave did not know the way out. They looked around everywhere, but there were no holes or openings, only this one gate through which they could seek to leave.

Purna said again:

From the beginning, all have been harmed by the conceit of self. The afflictions of sentient beings all arise and grow due to the conceit of self.

Ignorance of conceit, not knowing conceit, because of not knowing, is like a cycle not knowing its beginning, also like a tangled weave not knowing its head, also like a hempen cloth, also like an army when it is defeated, agitated and running in confusion, beings are unsettled in what is agitating, in this world and the next world, running without stopping, transmigrating in birth and death, unable to escape.

As I see it, all sentient beings are conditioned, arising from the combination of various causes and conditions.
